body:
### Problem

When there are multiple pages of the same section for one topic, `man <topic>` display the first found page. To see all the pages, use `man -a <topic>`.

My use case:

I have both CPP manual and POSXI.1 system library manual (including the standard C library part) installed and  configured in `MANPATH` to search.
```sh
export MANPATH="${HOME}/.cache/cppman:/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/share/man:/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/SDKs/MacOSX.sdk/usr/share/man:$MANPATH"
export MANPAGER='nvim +Man!'
alias man='man -a'
```

Then, when I run `man va_arg` (here `man` is `man -a`), it will use Neovim as the pager to open the CPP page of `va_arg` at first, after I type `q` to quit the page, it will open the next page of `va_arg` from the C library manual. This works great. 

However, in Neovim, this doesn't work.

- `:Man -a va_arg` will show error "man.lua: manpage name cannot start with '-'".

- `:Man va_arg` only shows the first page of `va_arg`, it seems that `man.lua` doesn't respect `alias man='man -a'` either.


### Expected behavior

Add `-a` option to `:Man` command, or add an option to configure the `man` plugin to use 'man -a' instead of 'man' as the backend command. Then `:Man -a <topoic>` or `:Man <topic>` will display all the pages found one by one like `man -a` does in the terminal (Neovim still works as the pager).
title: man.lua support `-a` option to display multiple man pages for one topic.
